Best Buy’s Black Friday event is officially here, and it’s slashing prices on dozens of digital Switch games. Many of these are also on sale on the official Nintendo eShop, but buying from Best Buy is the better option as you’ll get the full Gold Points for your purchase, whereas the eShop gives you an amount based on the discounted price. That means Best Buy is the best place to shop for digital Switch games this Black Friday, and there are some great options to choose from.

Arguably the best game on sale is The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom. It was Nintendo’s first $70 game when it was released in 2023, but right now you can pick it up for just $50. You’ll find hours of fun in its expansive open world, and the brilliant Ultrahand mechanic makes it easy to craft unique gadgets to help you zoom across its landscape or battle its most challenging enemies. At just $50, we can’t recommend it enough.

You won’t find the newly released Dragon Quest 3 HD-2D Remake on sale, but two other Dragon Quest games are down to some of their best prices of the year. Dragon Quest 11 S: Echoes of an Elusive Age is now $35 (was $50), offering a traditional console RPG experience with a surprisingly moving story and memorable cast, and it’s a great value at this discounted price. For something a bit different, you’ll find Dragon Quest Builders 2 for $35 (was $50).

Other notable deals include Doom Eternal Deluxe Editiion for $17.50 (was $70), Persona 5 Royal for $15 (was $60), and Super Monkey Ball: Banana Rumble for $25 (was $70). Plenty of other great digital Switch games from beloved series like Super Mario, Sonic the Hedgehog, Xenoblade Chronicles, and more are on sale for Black Friday, and you’ll find the best deals below. Note that some prices won't show up until you add the digital code to your shopping cart, but you can review the sale prices before checkout.

item.title: Destiny 2's Iron Banner Returns Soon With A Brand-New Armor Set And Rocket Sidearm
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/destiny-2s-iron-banner-returns-soon-with-a-brand-new-armor-set-and-rocket-sidearm/1100-6527954/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

It's a perfect time for Iron Wolves to be thankful as Destiny 2's Iron Banner event will make its return next week. The Iron Banner usually brings along new weapons and ornaments, and this event will be no different as it introduces both a new armor set and rocket sidearm into the the loot pool.

On Bungie's This Week In Destiny announcements, the name of the armor set was revealed--Iron Intent--with pieces "worthy of Weyloran, Nirwen, and Orewig" themselves. Players will know those names as great Iron Lords, who've all had weapons and ornaments named after them throughout the years. The Iron Banner will return to the game starting on November 26, with the match type of Control for the first week.

The armor has a Norse-adjacent aesthetic with the Titan helmet almost looking like a hammer with the Warlock mask having studded horns. All three have intricate braiding embossing up and down the plates. Destiny has had similar ornaments before with the Valhund set, but still very different in presentation.

Along with the Iron Intent set, the announcement teased the first-ever Stasis rocket sidearm. It also revealed that it would be possible to get the weapon with the Loose Change perk with Chill Clip perks. As Iron Banner events are now two weeks long, there's plenty of time to get the perfect roll on the new weapon. The few rocket sidearms in the game have proven to be excellent, and the current Artifact has a lot of Stasis weapon-centric perks, so it should be a pretty desirable weapon.

The previous Iron Banner brought new versions of old favorites, the Claws of the Wolf pulse rifle and Crimil's Dagger hand cannon. This will be the last time the banner is raised and Lord Saladin's sigil is lit during this episode, and if you missed out, it's a great time to make your enemies hear the howls and know fear.

item.title: Stalker 2 Gets Day-One Patch Improvements, But Problems Remain Across PC And Xbox
item.content:encoded:
https://www.gamespot.com/articles/stalker-2-gets-day-one-patch-improvements-but-problems-remain-across-pc-and-xbox/1100-6527951/?ftag=CAD-01-10abi2f

GameSpot may receive revenue from affiliate and advertising partnerships for sharing this content and from purchases through links.

Few video game developers have had to deal with the things that GSC Game World had to face while making Stalker 2: Heart of Chornobyl. The Ukrainian game developer behind this first-person shooter survival-horror title was derailed by Russia's invasion of its country in 2022. But the game was finally released earlier this month with some noticeable issues. Fortunately, a day-one patch has reportedly dealt with some of those problems, while others remain.

As noted by Eurogamer and Digital Foundry, the patch arrived after reviewers had already played through Stalker 2. The good news is that this patch seems to have significantly helped the game's frame-rate performance. But the site notes that "the game still suffers from everything to minor, amusing bugs to more serious issues and heavy CPU utilization." On Xbox Series X, the game is said to occasionally freeze entirely for a few seconds when visiting large towns, before continuing with an erratic rate of frames per second.

Overall, the first impression left by Stalker 2 remains positive. GameSpot's Richard Wakeling wrote in his Stalker 2 review notes that it "boldly sticks to the studio's vision of a seamless open-world survival shooter, which the series has always strived to be. It's rough around the edges and uncompromising in a way that is sometimes off-putting. Yet the series' emergent gameplay remains intact and is further complemented by a fascinating setting and the most accomplished combat in the series so far." However, Wakeling also reiterated many of the technical issues stated above, as well as crashes and other bugs that hampered the experience.

Xbox released the behind-the-scenes documentary War Game: The Making of Stalker 2 last month, which chronicles the ordeal that GSC Game World's team went through in order to complete the game during war time. Ultimately, many of the developers had to leave Ukraine to finish the development while others remained behind to fight for their country. That war continues to this day with no resolution in sight.
